marks: Signature and Date LLC, in pencil: [VG 1653]
medium: Black chalk, grey wash and traces of pen and brown ink
text: Jan van Goyen was the master of the peaceful landscape in Holland’s Golden Age. His paintings and drawings, which survive in great numbers, attest to his remarkable ability to capture the essence of daily village life. He was able to record detail or to suggest movement with seemingly effortless inflections of his chalk. Here he invites us to imagine trade and transport, gardening and horseshoeing, sturdy homes with hearths ablaze, all set on a low horizon beneath a towering sky. Lingering figures, reflections on the water, and slowly drifting smoke tell us that the weather is mild, but weather beaten trees tell us that this is not always so. Today, only the ring of the blacksmith’s hammer will pierce the calm.
title: River Landscape with Blacksmith at Work outside a Village
